repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Rural road program : bringing access
            to the rural poor

abstracts.cdata!:
A little over 10 years ago, only
            slightly more than one quarter of Peruvians living in rural
            areas had access to a road in good condition, hampering
            their efforts to get to markets, send their children to
            school, or reach health clinics. International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) joined Peru's
            government on a program that has rehabilitated 15,000
            kilometers (kms) of roads, creating 6,000 permanent jobs and
            500 microenterprises working on road maintenance.

            to the rural poor

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Connecting isolated villages to
            markets in Peru

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on the
            Rural Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project for Peru.
            This project will reduce rural poverty and integrate remote
            zones through the rehabilitation of the transportation network.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Rural Roads Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project achieved its primary
            development objectives in a satisfactory to highly
            satisfactory manner. The sustainability of the project is
            rated as likely. The long-term sustainability of the program
            requires that municipalities acquire institutional,
            technical, and financial capacity to thoroughly assume such
            responsibility, given their jurisdiction and responsibility
            over the rural road network. The overall performance of the
            World Bank is rated as highly satisfactory. The
            Borrower's overall performance is assessed as
            satisfactory to highly satisfactory. The implementation of
            this project was particularly rich in testing innovative
            approaches to communicating with rural communities and
            measuring outcomes in order to better understand the links
            between rural accessibility improvements and poverty. Three
            main lessons emerge related to building ownership, reaching
            the poor, and ultimately spurring positive socio-economic
            changes: 1) For effective poverty targeting, rural
            accessibility interventions must find the balance between
            poverty targeting and promotion of economic opportunities;
            2) continuous beneficiary participation invigorates project
            sustainability and becomes a driver for positive social
            change; and 3) common notions on what to expect from the
            involvement of the most impoverished rural communities in
            non-motorized transport interventions need to be reformulated.
